question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (nâ‰¥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as âœ“, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,âœ“|âœ“|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|âœ“,x|âœ“|âœ“ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only âœ“|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.

(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors: \(p1 & p2\)
(2) Either \(\sqrt{3}\) or 5 is irrational: \(p3 || p4\)

response:
Let's systematically address each formula and determine their truth and falsity values carefully.

### (1) Formula: ~(p1&p2&~p3)
This formula represents the negation of the conjunction of p1, p2, and the negation of p3.

#### Truth values:
The formula ~(p1&p2&~p3) is true when the conjunction p1&p2&~p3 is false.

##### p1&p2&~p3 is false when:
- At least one of p1 or p2 is false.
- Or, p3 is true, making ~p3 false.

So, ~(p1&p2&~p3) is true for the following assignments:
- p1 is false (x) or
- p2 is false (x) or
- p3 is true (âœ“)

Therefore, the truth assignments for ~(p1&p2&~p3) are:
- x|x|x, x|x|âœ“, x|âœ“|x, x|âœ“|âœ“, âœ“|x|x, âœ“|x|âœ“, âœ“|âœ“|âœ“

#### Falsity values:
The formula ~(p1&p2&~p3) is false when p1&p2&~p3 is true.

##### p1&p2&~p3 is true when:
- p1 is true (âœ“), and
- p2 is true (âœ“), and
- p3 is false (x), making ~p3 true.

Therefore, the false assignment for ~(p1&p2&~p3) is:
- âœ“|âœ“|x

### (2) Formula: (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)
This formula represents the logical implication where the antecedent is ~p1&p2 and the consequent is p1 if and only if p3.

#### Truth values:
The formula (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3) is false only when the antecedent (~p1&p2) is true and the consequent (p1=p3) is false.

##### ~p1&p2 is true when:
- p1 is false (x), and
- p2 is true (âœ“).

##### p1=p3 is false when:
- p1 and p3 have different truth values (one is true, the other is false).

So, the formula is false when:
- p1 = x, p2 = âœ“, p3 = âœ“
- p1 = x, p2 = âœ“, p3 = x

Therefore, the truth assignments for (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3):
- All other combinations where either ~p1&p2 is false, or p1=p3 is true.

#### Falsity values:
The formula (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3) is false when ~p1&p2 is true and p1=p3 is false:
- x|âœ“|âœ“, and
- x|âœ“|x.

Thus, the correct assignment evaluations are:

### Answer:

```
[[T:x|x|x, x|x|âœ“, x|âœ“|x, x|âœ“|âœ“, âœ“|x|x, âœ“|x|âœ“, âœ“|âœ“|âœ“; F:âœ“|âœ“|x]; [T:âœ“|âœ“|âœ“, x|âœ“|âœ“, âœ“|âœ“|x, âœ“|x|âœ“, âœ“|x|x, x|x|âœ“, x|x|x; F:x|âœ“|x, x|âœ“|âœ“]]
```

title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (nâ‰¥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as âœ“, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,âœ“|âœ“|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|âœ“,x|âœ“|âœ“ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only âœ“|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (nâ‰¥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as âœ“, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,âœ“|âœ“|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|âœ“,x|âœ“|âœ“ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only âœ“|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (nâ‰¥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as âœ“, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,âœ“|âœ“|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|âœ“,x|âœ“|âœ“ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only âœ“|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

   - All combinations result in a true assignment, hence: **Truth Formula**.

#### Formula (2): (p1=::>~p1)=::>~p2
1. **Truth Table Creation for (p1=::>~p1)=::>~p2**
   - Let's examine the assignments of propositions p1 and p2.

response:
To determine the type of the formulas, we need to assess their truth values under all possible assignments for the propositions \( p1 \) and \( p2 \). We are given that \( p1=::>(p1||p2) \) is a Truth Formula, and \( \neg(p1=::>p2) \& p2 \) is a Falsehood Formula.

### Step-by-Step Breakdown:

1. **Analyze the given Truth Formula:**
\[ p1=::>(p1||p2) \]

This formula states that \( p1 \) implies \( (p1 \text{ or } p2) \),
which is indeed always true:
- If \( p1 \) is true, then \( p1 \text{ or } p2 \) is true (since \( p1 \) is already true).
- If \( p1 \) is false, then \( p1=::>(p1||p2) \) is still true, because a false premise implies anything.

Hence, \( p1=::>(p1||p2) \) is always true.

2. **Analyze the given Falsehood Formula:**
\[ \neg(p1=::>p2) \& p2 \]

This formula states that \( \neg(p1 \rightarrow p2) \text{ and } p2 \):
- \( p1=::>p2 \) is false if \( p1 \) is true and \( p2 \) is false.
- \( \neg(p1 \rightarrow p2) \) means that \( p1 \text{ and not } p2 \), which must be combined with \( p2 \).

So, for the entire formula \( \neg(p1=::>p2) \& p2 \) to be false:
- \( \neg(p1=::>p2) \) must be true, implying \( p1 \) is true and \( p2 \) is false.
- But it is also combined with \( p2 \), which must be true.

Since these conditions contradict each other (both \( p2 \) and \( \neg p2 \)), the entire formula \( \neg(p1=::>p2) \& p2 \) is false under all assignments.

### Formulas to Determine:

#### Formula (1):
\[ (p1=::>(p1||p2))\&(\neg(p1=::>p2)\&p2) \]

- Given that \( p1=::>(p1||p2) \) is always true.
- Given that \( \neg(p1=::>p2)\&p2 \) is always false.
- Combining a true proposition with a false proposition using '\&' results in false.

Thus, (1) is a **Falsehood Formula**.

#### Formula (2):
\[ (p1=::>(p1||p2))\||(\neg(p1=::>p2)\&p2) \]

- \( p1=::>(p1||p2) \) is always true.
- Something true combined with any other proposition using '\||' (or) results in true.

Thus, (2) is a **Truth Formula**.

### Question:

response:
To determine the validity of the given equivalences according to the 16 Basic Equivalences, we will examine and transform each statement step by step.

#### Equivalence (1): \((p > q) & (p > r) ::=:: (p > (q | r))\)

1. Expand the implications using rule (10): \(A > B ::=:: !A | B\)
    - \(p > q ::=:: !p | q\)
    - \(p > r ::=:: !p | r\)
    Thus, \((p > q) & (p > r)\) equivalently becomes \((!p | q) & (!p | r)\).

2. Now expand the implication on the right side using the same rule:
    - \(p > (q | r) ::=:: !p | (q | r)\)

3. Both sides thus become:
    - Left: \((!p | q) & (!p | r)\)
    - Right: \(!p | (q | r)\)

4. Apply distributive property to the left side using rule (5):
    \[
    (!p | q) & (!p | r) ::=:: !p | (q & r)
    \]

5. Observe that \( !p | (q & r) \) is not the same as \( !p | (q | r) \).

Based on these steps, \((!p | q) & (!p | r)\) is not logically equivalent to \(!p | (q | r)\).

**Conclusion**: The answer for (1) is No (B).

#### Equivalence (2): \(! (p = q) ::=:: (p | q) & ! (p & q)\)

1. Expand \(p = q\) using rule (11): \(A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)\)

    - Therefore, \( ! (p = q) ::=:: ! ((p > q) & (q > p)) \)

2. Apply De Morgan's Law (rule (6)) to the right side:
    \[
    ! ((p > q) & (q > p)) ::=:: ! (p > q) | ! (q > p)
    \]

3. Expand the negated implications using rule (10):
    - \( ! (p > q) ::=:: ! (!p | q) ::=:: p & !q \)
    - \( ! (q > p) ::=:: ! (!q | p) ::=:: q & !p\)
    - Thus, \( ! (p > q) | ! (q > p) ::=:: (p & !q) | (q & !p) \)

4. Simplify \((p | q) & ! (p & q)\) using rule (6):
    - \((p & !q) | (q & !p)\) should be simplified to \((p | q) & !(p & q)\)

Based on these steps, \((p & !q) | (q & !p)\) is logically equivalent to \((p | q) & !(p & q)\).

**Conclusion**: The answer for (2) is Yes (A).

### Final Answer:
Thus, the formatted answer is:

[[B];[A]]

    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `â‡‘`
    - NOR is represented by `â‡“`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A â‡‘ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A â‡“ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

Simplify the expression using basic equivalences:

\[ (\neg p \& q) \& ((\neg p \& \neg q) | (p \& q)) \& (q \& r) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q) \& ((\neg p \& \neg q) \& (q \& r) | (p \& q) \& (q \& r)) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q) \& ((\neg p \& \neg q \& q \& r) | (p \& q \& q \& r)) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q) \& ((0) | (p \& q \& r)) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q) \& (0) \text{ (since } p \& q \& q \& r \text{ is false)} \]
\[ \equiv 0 \]

So,

\[ B1 \& C2 \& D3 ::=:: 0 \]

2. Now calculate \( B1 \& C3 \& D2 \):

\[ B1 = \neg p \& q \]
\[ C3 = \neg p \& q \]
\[ D2 = (\neg q \& r) | (q \& \neg r) \]

Combining these, we get:

\[ B1 \& C3 \& D2 = (\neg p \& q) \& (\neg p \& q) \& ((\neg q \& r) | (q \& \neg r)) \]

Simplify the expression:

\[ (\neg p \& q) \& (\neg p \& q) \& ((\neg q \& r) | (q \& \neg r)) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q \& (\neg q \& r)) | (\neg p \& q \& (q \& \neg r)) \]
\[ \equiv (\neg p \& q \& \neg q \& r) | (\neg p \& q \& q \& \neg r) \]
\[ \equiv (0) | (\neg p \& q \& q \& \neg r) \]
\[ \equiv \neg p \& q \& \neg r \]

So,

\[ B1 \& C3 \& D2 ::=:: \neg p \& q \& \neg r \]

3. Next, calculate \( B2 \& C1 \& D3 \):

\[ B2 = (\neg p \& \neg q) | (p \& q) \]
\[ C1 = p \& \neg q \]
\[ D3 = q \& r \]

Combining these, we get:

\[ B2 \& C1 \& D3 = ((\neg p \& \neg q) | (p \& q)) \& (p \& \neg q) \& (q \& r) \]

Simplify the expression:

\[ \equiv (( \neg p \& \neg q) ) \]

\[p& q= p\]

So,

\[ B2 \& C1 \& D3 ::=::0  \]

\[ D1 = \neg q \& \neg r \]

Combining these, we get:

\[ B2 \& C3 \& D1 = ((\neg p \& \neg q) | (p \& q)) \& (\neg p \& q) \& (\neg q \& \neg r) \]

Simplify the expression:

\[ \equiv ((\neg p \& \neg q \& \neg p \& q \& \neg q \& \neg r) | (p \& q) )\]

So,

\[ B2 \& C3 \& D1 ::=:: 0 \]

So,

    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B

    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A

    (16) A â‡“ B ::=:: !A & !B

Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."

q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou."

Person B:p&!q

B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).

C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).

D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).

(6) What does B3&C2&D1 simplify to?
(7) What does E finally simplify to?

title: Equivalence Calculus
rule_content:
1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `â‡‘`
    - NOR is represented by `â‡“`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)

### Logic Rule:

1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `â‡‘`
    - NOR is represented by `â‡“`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A
    (4) (A | B) | C ::=:: A | (B | C), (A & B) & C ::=:: A & (B & C)
    (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), A & (B | C) ::=:: (A & B) | (A & C)
    (6) !(A | B) ::=:: !A & !B, !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B
    (7) A | (A & B) ::=:: A, A & (A | B) ::=:: A
    (8) A | !A ::=:: 1
    (9) A & !A ::=:: 0
    (10) A > B ::=:: !A | B
    (11) A = B ::=:: (A > B) & (B > A)
    (12) A > B ::=:: !B > !A
    (13) A = B ::=:: !A = !B
    (14) (A > B) & (A > !B) ::=:: !A
    (15) A â‡‘ B ::=:: !A | !B
    (16) A â‡“ B ::=:: !A & !B
3. Equivalence Calculation Rules:
    - The final expression should be completely represented using `|`, `&`, and `!`, without retaining `>` and `=`.
4. Truth Value Judgment Steps:
    - Define the practical problem to be judged as simple propositions and symbolize them.
    - Use simple propositions to express the formula based on each person's description.
    - Combine the information of who is true and who is false to write the final logical expression.
    - Use the above equivalences to derive and judge the truth of the expression.

### Question:
During a break at a seminar, three attendees tried to determine where Professor Wang is from based on his accent. Their statements were as follows:

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."
Let p denote "Professor Wang is from Suzhou,"
q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai,"
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou."

Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions.
Represent each person's statement:
Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:

B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

Similarly, define the analogous expressions for Person B:
C1=p&!q.(Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2=(p & q) | (!p & !q).(Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3=!p&q.(Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1=!q&!r.(Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2=(!q&r)|(q&!r).(Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3=q&r.(Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

According to Professor Wang's remarks, the final logical expression
E=(B1&C2&D3)|(B1&C3&D2)|(B2&C1&D3)|(B2&C3&D1)|(B3&C1&D2)|(B3&C2&D1)

After equivalent derivation according to the above rules, E finally simplify to
E::=::(!p&q&!r)|(p&!q&r).

Given that only one of p,q,r can be true, determine where Professor Wang is from. Who got everything right? Who got half right? Who got everything wrong?
Each choice should be selected from the three options provided.
Please provide the corresponding answers. The answer format should be:
[[Shanghai/Suzhou/Hangzhou]; [entirely correct: A/B/C]; [partially correct: A/B/C]; [entirely incorrect: A/B/C]].

### Answer:
response:
Given the equivalences and deriving the final simplified expression `E ::=:: (!p&q&!r) | (p&!q&r)`, we can evaluate the truth values based on the conditions where exactly one of `p, q, r` is true:

Let's evaluate the two cases where only one proposition is true:

1. **Case 1: Professor Wang is from Shanghai (`q` is true, `p` and `r` are false)**
    - `p = false`
    - `q = true`
    - `r = false`

   Substituting into the simplified expression `E`:
   `E ::=:: (!p&q&!r)`
   - `!p = true`
   - `q = true`
   - `!r = true`

   Therefore, `(!p & q & !r) = true`.

   Now checking the statement evaluations for Person A, B, and C:
   - **Person A:**
     - `!p & q = true & true = true`
     - This means Person A is entirely correct.

   - **Person B:**
     - `p & !q = false & false = false`
     - This means Person B is entirely incorrect.

   - **Person C:**
     - `!q & !r = false & true = false`
     - `!q = false, !r = true`
     - `(!q & r) | (q & !r) = false | true = true`
     - This means Person C is partially correct.

2. **Case 2: Professor Wang is from Suzhou (`p` is true, `q` and `r` are false)**
    - `p = true`
    - `q = false`
    - `r = false`

   Substituting into the simplified expression `E`:
   `E ::=:: (p & !q & r)`
   - `p = true`
   - `!q = true`
   - `r = false`

   Therefore, `(p & !q & r) = false`.

   This case does not satisfy `E`.

3. **Case 3: Professor Wang is from Hangzhou (`r` is true, `p` and `q` are false)**
    - `p = false`
    - `q = false`
    - `r = true`

   Substituting into the simplified expression `E`:
   `E ::=:: (!p & q & !r)`
   - `!p = true`
   - `q = false`
   - `!r = false`

   Therefore, `(!p & q & !r) = false`.

   This case does not satisfy `E`.

Thus, the only case that satisfies `E` is when Professor Wang is from **Shanghai**.

Final Answers:
1. **Where is Professor Wang from?**
   - Professor Wang is from **Shanghai**.

2. **Who got everything right?**
   - Person **A** got everything right.

3. **Who got half right?**
   - Person **C** got half right.

4. **Who got everything wrong?**
   - Person **B** got everything wrong.

Correct format:
```plaintext
[[Shanghai]; [entirely correct: A]; [partially correct: C]; [entirely incorrect: B]]
```

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of pâˆ§q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨Â¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).

For example, the false assignment of Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨Â¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of pâˆ§q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.

For example, the false assignment of Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨Â¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.

- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of pâˆ§q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of Â¬pâˆ¨Â¬qâˆ¨Â¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Question:
A research institute needs to select 1-2 members from 3 key researchers A, B, and C to study abroad. Due to work requirements, the selection must satisfy the following conditions:

1. If A goes, then C must go.
2. If B goes, then C cannot go.
3. If C does not go, then either A or B can go.

Let p: A goes
Let q: B goes
Let r: C goes

Based on the given conditions, the formula can be derived as:
(p â†’ r) âˆ§ (q â†’ Â¬r) âˆ§ (Â¬r â†’ (p âˆ¨ q))

The true assignments of this formula are the feasible selection schemes. Through derivation, we get:
(p â†’ r) âˆ§ (q â†’ Â¬r) âˆ§ (Â¬r â†’ (p âˆ¨ q)) â†” (Â¬p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r) âˆ¨ (Â¬p âˆ§ q âˆ§ Â¬r) âˆ¨ (p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r), which can be denoted as m1 âˆ¨ m2 âˆ¨ m5. 
Based on the three true assignments represented, what are the feasible selection schemes? 

Only give the letters of the people selected to go, separated by commas within a scheme, and different schemes separated by []; format: [[];[];..].

### Answer:
response:
Based on the derived formula and the true assignments represented by \( m1 \), \( m2 \), and \( m5 \), we can determine the feasible selection schemes as follows:

- \( m1 \) corresponds to the binary number 001, which represents Â¬p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r. This means A does not go, B does not go, and C goes. The selection scheme is [C].
- \( m2 \) corresponds to the binary number 010, which represents Â¬p âˆ§ q âˆ§ Â¬r. This means A does not go, B goes, and C does not go. The selection scheme is [B].
- \( m5 \) corresponds to the binary number 101, which represents p âˆ§ Â¬q âˆ§ r. This means A goes, B does not go, and C goes. The selection scheme is [A,C].

Therefore, the feasible selection schemes are:

[[C];[B];[A,C]]

     - **\( \{p \vee q\} \) with \( \{q \vee \neg r\} \):**
       - Resolves to \( \{p \vee \neg r\} \), which is not in \( S_1 \), so add to \( S_2 \).
     - **\( \{p \vee q\} \) with \( \{q \vee r\} \):**

     - **\( \{p \vee \neg q\} \) with \( \{q \vee \neg r\} \):**

\]

We will apply the given Resolution Algorithm to check for a satisfying assignment:

### Initialization
- \(S0 = \emptyset\)
- \(S1 = \{ (p âˆ¨ q), (p âˆ¨ Â¬q), (Â¬p âˆ¨ r) \} \)
- \(S2 = \emptyset\)

### Steps

1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\)**
   
   Since \(S0\) is initially empty, no resolutions are performed in this step.

2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\)**:
   
   - **C1 = (p âˆ¨ q), C2 = (p âˆ¨ Â¬q)**
     - They cannot be resolved as none are complements.
   
   - **C1 = (p âˆ¨ q), C2 = (Â¬p âˆ¨ r)**

     - \(dispel((p âˆ¨ q), (Â¬p âˆ¨ r)) = q âˆ¨ r\) 
     - New clause \(C = (q âˆ¨ r)\)
     - Add \(C\) to \(S2\)

   - **C1 = (p âˆ¨ Â¬q), C2 = (Â¬p âˆ¨ r)**
     - \(L = p\), \(L' = Â¬p\)
     - \(dispel((p âˆ¨ Â¬q), (Â¬p âˆ¨ r)) = Â¬q âˆ¨ r\) 
     - New clause \(C = (Â¬q âˆ¨ r)\)
     - Add \(C\) to \(S2\)

   Now, \(S2 = \{ (q âˆ¨ r), (Â¬q âˆ¨ r) \}\)

3. **Check \(S2\)**
   - \(S2\) is not empty, proceed to the next iteration:
     - Set \(S1 = S2\)
     - Set \(S0 = \{(p âˆ¨ q), (p âˆ¨ Â¬q), (Â¬p âˆ¨ r)\}\)
     - Clear \(S2\), so \(S2 = \emptyset\)

1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\)**
   - No new resolvent clauses as they are similar resolutions as the first iteration.
 
2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\)**:
   
   - **C1 = (q âˆ¨ r), C2 = (Â¬q âˆ¨ r)**
     - \(L = q\), \(L' = Â¬q\)
     - \(dispel((q âˆ¨ r), (Â¬q âˆ¨ r)) = r\) 
     - New clause \(C = r\)
     - Add \(C\) to \(S2\)

   Now, \(S2 = \{ r \}\)

3. **Check \(S2\)**
   - \(S2\) contains new elements, proceed to next iteration:
     - Set \(S1 = S2\)
     - Add \(S0\) elements to previous elements to maintain tracking \(S0 = \{(p âˆ¨ q), (p âˆ¨ Â¬q), (Â¬p âˆ¨ r),(q âˆ¨ r), (Â¬q âˆ¨ r)\}\)
     - Clear \(S2\), so \(S2 = \emptyset\)

### Third Iteration

1. **Resolve clauses in \(S0\) and \(S1\)**
   - No new resolvent clauses as they are similar resolutions.
  
2. **Resolve clauses in \(S1\)**:
   
   - There are no pairs in \(S1\) to resolve as it contains single clause

  Now, \(S2 = \emptyset\)

3. **Check \(S2\)**
   - \(S2\) is empty.

\[

To construct a truth table for an AND gate, we need to understand that an AND gate outputs true (or +) only when all its inputs are true (or +). In other words, the output is powered only if both inputs are powered.

For the AND gate, there's typically 2 inputs, represented as I1 and I2. The output of the AND gate is represented as O.

Here's the formatted truth table:

```
[[I1, I2, O]; [+,-,-]; [-,+,-]; [+, +, +]]
```

Explanation:

- If I1 is powered (+) and I2 is not powered (-), the output O is not powered (-).
- If I1 is not powered (-) and I2 is powered (+), the output O is not powered (-).
- If both I1 and I2 are powered (+), the output O is powered (+).
- If both I1 and I2 are not powered (-), the output O is not powered (-).

So, the complete truth table for an AND gate:

1. `I1 = +`, `I2 = -`, `O = -`
2. `I1 = -`, `I2 = +`, `O = -`
3. `I1 = +`, `I2 = +`, `O = +`
4. `I1 = -`, `I2 = -`, `O = -`

Formatted as per the specified notation:

```
[[I1, I2, O]; [+,-,-]; [-,+,-]; [+, +, +]; [-,-,-]]
```

rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Conjunction: Use &

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.

"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) â‡’ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).

"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) â‡’ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) â‡’ H(x, y))).

needle: Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
- Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
- Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
- Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
- Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.
title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

Examples:

- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

- [4]: Some products are unqualified. (Particular Affirmative, I)

- Relationship between [3] and [4]: A (since E and I are contradictory)

[[B];[A]]

title: Derivative Reasoning of Propositional Logic
rule_content:
Method A
- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All S is not non-P.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All S is non-P.
    3. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some S is not non-P.
    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.

- Change the quality from negative to affirmative.
- Replace "top-grade" with its contrary, which is "non-top-grade."

"Some products are non-top-grade."

- Property: They cannot both be false, but they can both be true.

(4) % Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and $p; #Â¬p and $Â¬p
- Property: They can both be true or both be false.

(12) !$!p â†’ !#!p
(13) #p â†’ p
(14) #!p â†’ !p
(15) p â†’ $p
(16) !p â†’ $!p

### Question:
Based on the truth modal reasoning formula 16, what can be inferred from "Team A did not win the championship"?

A. Team A  won the championship.
B. Team A will not win the championship.
C. Team A cannot win the championship.
D. Team A might not have won the championship.

Please answer in the format of [[A/B/C/D]].

### Answer:
response:
First, let's translate the given statement "Team A did not win the championship" into the propositional logic notation. Let's assume:

- p: Team A won the championship.
- !p: Team A did not win the championship.

Given that "Team A did not win the championship" translates to !p.

Now, let's use the modal logic inference formula (16):
\[ !p \rightarrow \$!p \]

This means:
"If it is known that Team A did not win the championship (!p), it is possible that Team A did not win the championship (\$!p)."

Translating this into the available options:
A. Team A won the championship. (p)
B. Team A will not win the championship. (# !p)
C. Team A cannot win the championship. (# !p)
D. Team A might not have won the championship. ($ !p)

From this analysis, we see that option D "Team A might not have won the championship" is directly supported by the inference formula.

Thus, the correct answer is:

[[D]]

needle: - Belief Axiom: `B_p â†’ p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p â†’ p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p â†’ BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p âˆ§ B_{Â¬p} â†’ âŠ¥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `Â¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p â†’ Â¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

title: Enumerative Inductive Reasoning
rule_content:
1. * Induction
(1) Definition:* induction involves inferring a general conclusion based on observing specific instances within a class.
(2) Symbolic Representation:
- `e_i` represents the ith instance.
- `P(e_i)` denotes that instance `e_i` has property `P`.
- `forall e` indicates "for all instances `e`".
- The conclusion `forall e, P(e)` signifies that all instances `e` possess property `P`.
(3) Rules:
- Premise: Observations of instances `e_1, e_2, ..., e_k` all possessing property `P`, where these instances are part of class `S`.
    - Symbolically: `P(e_1), P(e_2), ..., P(e_k)`
- Conclusion: Based on limited observation, it is inferred that all instances `e` in class `S` possess property `P`.
    - Symbolically: `forall e in S, P(e)` (this is a conjecture).

2. Î¦ Induction

(1) Definition:Î¦ induction derives a general conclusion about all members of a class based on examining the properties of every individual in that class.
(2) Symbolic Representation:
- `E` represents the set of all individuals in the class.
- `P(E)` denotes that every individual in set `E` possesses property `P`.
(3) Rules:
- Premise: Every individual `e_i` in set `E` possesses property `P`, where `e_1, e_2, ..., e_n` are all members of class `S`.
    - Symbolically: `P(e_1), P(e_2), ..., P(e_n)`
- Conclusion: All members of class `S` possess property `P`.
    - Symbolically: `P(E)`

3. Key Differences
- * Induction:
    - Premise: Based on observations of some instances.
    - Conclusion: Inferred for all instances.

    - Premise: Based on observations of all instances.
    - Conclusion: Determined for all instances.

title: Logical Methods for Exploring Cause and Effect Relationships
rule_content:
Five Methods for Exploring Causal Relationships

1. Method â¸®:
- If S and P occur together in multiple cases while other conditions A, B, C, E, F, etc., differ:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) S C D     P
    - (3) S E F     P
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

2. Method Ø†:
- If P occurs when S is present and does not occur when S is absent:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) - A B     P
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

3. Method ê™®:
- Positive group: S and P occur together, while other conditions A, B, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
    - Positive group
        - (1) S A B     P
        - (2) S C D    P
        - (3) S E F     P
    - Negative group: S is absent, P is also absent, and other conditions A, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
        - Negative group
            - (1') - A C    -
            - (2') - D E    -
            - (3') - B F    -
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

4. Method âµ£:
- When changes in S correspond to changes in P:
    - (1) S1 A B     P1
    - (2) S2 A B    P2
    - (3) S3 A B    P3
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

5. Method âš˜:
- When S, A, B, C have causal relationships with P, X, Y, Z, and the causal relationships between A and X, B and Y, C and Z are known:
    - (1) A has a causal relationship with X
    - (2) B has a causal relationship with Y
    - (3) C has a causal relationship with Z
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

question:
In 1973, the comrades of the Shanghai Water Geology Team carried out extensive investigations in order to find out the main cause of the subsidence of the city of Shanghai. During the investigation, it was found that the ground subsidence was more serious in several working areas in the east and west of the city. 
The conditions of these work areas were different, such as the layout of workplaces, geographical conditions, and so on, which were totally different. 
However, they later found that in the several workplaces with different conditions, there was one common situation, i.e. "the amount of subsidence was greater in areas with a relatively higher concentration of textiles".

In response, scientists conducted an experiment. 
They divided a number of wheat and nickel white animals into two groups: one with salivary glands that had been removed manually, and one with normal wheat and nickel white, which differed only in this case, but were identical in all other cases. Then bruise it. 
The result was that the wound healed much faster in the normal millets than in those whose salivary glands had been removed.

- **Method ê™®**:

- **Method âµ£**:
  - Concerns corresponding changes in S to changes in P.
  - Not concerned with changes over different stages but compares two conditions of the same stage.

- **Method âš˜**:
  - Considers independent known causal relationships between A, B, C and P, X, Y, Z.
  - Not applicable, as there is no reference to multiple causal relationships between other variables.

### Suitable Method:

The observed causal relationship likely falls under Method B, which is determined by verifying the presence (faster healing) and absence (slower healing) of the effect in relation to the presence or absence of the cause.

[[B]]

needle: - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.
title: Statistical Reasoning
rule_content:
1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `âˆ€x âˆˆ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) â‰ˆ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) â‰ˆ Pr(A, P2)`.

- We can infer that all 50 students in the class will get an A.

``` 
[[100%]]
```

response:

Pr(AQI < 50) â‰ˆ \frac{k}{n} = \frac{4}{5} = 0.8 
\]

### [[80%]]

### Question:
A company performs quality testing on its products and randomly selects 50 products from a batch of 1,000, resulting in 2 defective products. Using the P-Generalization rule, estimate the rate of defective products for the entire batch.

Please give your answer in [[number%]] format.

### Answer:
response:
Let's solve this question using the P-Generalization Rule as defined in the instructions.

### Calculation:
1. We have a sample size of 50 (`n = 50`).
2. In this sample, 2 products are defective (`k = 2`).
3. According to the P-Generalization Rule: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) â‰ˆ k/n`.

### Applying the P-Generalization Rule:
- `P(Defective, 2, 50)`: This means that 2 out of 50 products in the sample are defective.
- We need to estimate the rate of defective products for the entire batch.

Using the formula:
\[ Pr(A) â‰ˆ \frac{k}{n} \]

Substitute the given values:
\[ Pr(Defective) â‰ˆ \frac{2}{50} \]

### Calculating the proportion:
\[ Pr(Defective) â‰ˆ 0.04 \]

### Converting to percentage:
\[ 0.04 \times 100 = 4\% \]

### Answer:
The estimated rate of defective products for the entire batch is [[4%]].

    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

    - Symbol: `C`

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `âˆ€x âˆˆ P, A(x)`.

C. LS Paradox

title: Induction Paradox
rule_content:
1. GB Paradox

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 â†’ p
- q_2 â†’ p
- q_1 âˆ§ q_2 â†’ âŠ¥

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Universal hypothesis âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x)).
- According to the confirmation standard, R(a)âˆ§B(a) confirms âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x)) is equivalent to âˆ€x(Â¬B(x)â†’Â¬R(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, Â¬B(b)âˆ§Â¬R(b) also confirms âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x)).
- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x))
- R(a)âˆ§B(a)â†’âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x))
- âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x))â‰¡âˆ€x(Â¬B(x)â†’Â¬R(x))
- Â¬B(b)âˆ§Â¬R(b)â†’âˆ€x(R(x)â†’B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 âˆ§ r_2 âˆ§ ... âˆ§ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 âˆ§ r_2 âˆ§ ... âˆ§ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 âˆ§ r_2 âˆ§ ... âˆ§ r_n â†’ Reasonable
- If r_1 âˆ§ r_2 âˆ§ ... âˆ§ r_n âˆ§ r_n+1 â†’ âŠ¥, then reassess the reasonableness.

title: Speech Acts
rule_content:
Custom Speech Act Classification Rules

1. Assertives

- Purpose: To commit the speaker to the truth of the expressed proposition.
- Adaptation Direction: From words to the world (*)
- Psychological State: Belief (â™¥)
- Formula: *â™¥(p)
- Common Verbs: Assert, affirm, deny, state, notify, remind, oppose, forecast, report.

title: Cooperative Principle
rule_content:
Custom Cooperation Principles

1. C* Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not let your statement be weaker in information than what your knowledge allows, unless a stronger statement conflicts with the Information Principle.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CQ1: If the speaker says A(w), and <s, w> brackets the words in order of information strength with s (strong) followed by w (weak), A(s) entails A(w), then it can be inferred that K~(A(s)), meaning the speaker knows that the stronger information cannot be established.
    - CQ2: The speaker states A(w), which does not entail the content of the embedded sentence Q, but the content of Q is entailed by the stronger information A(s), and {s, w} form a contrast set, then it can be deduced that ~K(Q), meaning the speaker does not know whether Q can be established.

2. C% Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Minimalization Criterion - Speak as little as possible, only speak to the minimum extent necessary to achieve the purpose of communication.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CI1: Assume that the relationship between the objects and time in the sentence follows the convention unless there is clear evidence to the contrary.
    - CI2: If a certain existence or fact exactly matches the confirmed situation, it is set that this is what the sentence is saying. The Information Principle actually refers to the speaker striving to "speak as little as possible," while the hearer strives to "expand the information" until fully grasping the intention of the speech.

3. C! Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not use lengthy, obscure, or marked expressions without reason.
(2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.

response:
Given the provided scenario:

A: "Do you have tickets for tonight's movie?"
B: "I bought two tickets."
C: "I managed to get two tickets."

Let's analyze it step-by-step in line with the prescribed logic rules:

1. **C* Principle (Custom Cooperation Principle with Speaker's Criterion and Hearer's Inference):**
   - This principle involves statements of varying information strength and the knowledge of the speaker.
   - In this conversation, B's statement ("I bought two tickets") and C's statement ("I managed to get two tickets") don't seem to fit the context of information strength and speaker's knowledge about weaker and stronger statements.
   
2. **C% Principle (Minimalization Criterion and Hearer's Inference):**
   - This principle involves speaking minimally to achieve the communication purpose while the hearer expands the information.
   - While B speaks minimally with "I bought two tickets,â€ C elaborates by saying "managed to get," which goes against the minimalization part of the C% Principle.
   
3. **C! Principle (Avoiding lengthy, obscure expressions unless necessary):**
   - This principle involves avoiding unnecessary lengthy expressions unless thereâ€™s a specific reason.
   - C uses "managed to get" to imply that obtaining the tickets was difficult and required effort. This goes beyond just â€œI boughtâ€ to provide additional information about the difficulty and effort involved.
   - Hence, C uses a marked expression to convey a specific nuance regarding their effort in getting the tickets, fitting the C! Principle.

Given this analysis, the correct principle that C's use aligns with is:

**[[C]]**

(2) Hearer's Inference:

2. C% Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Minimalization Criterion - Speak as little as possible, only speak to the minimum extent necessary to achieve the purpose of communication.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CI1: Assume that the relationship between the objects and time in the sentence follows the convention unless there is clear evidence to the contrary.
    - CI2: If a certain existence or fact exactly matches the confirmed situation, it is set that this is what the sentence is saying. The Information Principle actually refers to the speaker striving to "speak as little as possible," while the hearer strives to "expand the information" until fully grasping the intention of the speech.

3. C! Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not use lengthy, obscure, or marked expressions without reason.
(2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.

title: Definitions
rule_content:
1. Intensional Definitions

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) âš¯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) âŒ˜ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) âš’ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ïž Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) â˜– Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ñ¬ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ï¿¥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) â„µ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) â„“ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) âˆ‡ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) âš¯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) âŒ˜ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) âš’ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ïž Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) â˜– Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ñ¬ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) â„µ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) â„“ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) âˆ‡ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

question:
"Looking at the history of the development of science and technology around the world, many scientists' important inventions and creations were made during their prime, when their thinking was most agile. Copernicus was 38 when he proposed the heliocentric theory; Newton and Leibniz were 22 and 28 respectively when they invented calculus; Darwin was 22 during his global voyage and later wrote the famous "On the Origin of Species"; Edison was 29 when he invented the phonograph and 31 when he invented the light bulb; Bell was 29 when he invented the telephone; The Curies discovered the radioactivity of thorium, polonium, and radium at the age of 31, won their first Nobel Prize, and later discovered two new elements, winning a second Nobel Prize at the age of 46; Einstein was only 26 when he proposed the special theory of relativity and 37 when he proposed the general theory of relativity; Lee and Yang were 30 and 34 respectively when they proposed the law of parity non-conservation in weak interactions. Natural science is like this, and many outstanding social scientists and politicians have also basically created their outstanding achievements from a young age."

What argumentation method does this use?

A.E+ Method
B.Syl+ Method
C.Metaph+ Method
D.Case+ Method
E.Contra- Method
F.Elim- Method

Please give your answers in [[A/B/C/D/E/F]] format.
needle: E+ Method: Using specific instances to argue for the truth of a proposition.
title: Argumentation
rule_content:
Custom Argumentation Method Rules

1. Direct Argumentation Methods

- E+ Method: Using specific instances to argue for the truth of a proposition.
- Syl+ Method: Using universal propositions as premises and supporting conclusions through syllogistic reasoning.
- Metaph+ Method: Using metaphors to argue for the truth of a topic.
- Case+ Method: When it is necessary to prove that a proposition holds true under various conditions, prove its truthfulness by discussing each case separately.

2. Indirect Argumentation Methods

- Contra- Method: Indirectly confirming the truth of the original proposition by refuting the contrary proposition that contradicts the original one. For example, proving the necessity of improving scientific and cultural levels by negating the contrary proposition that "party and government leaders do not need to improve their scientific and cultural levels."
- Elim- Method: Indirectly determining the original proposition to be true by eliminating other possibilities related to the original proposition as false. For example, supporting the view that learning science and technology and resisting decadent culture by eliminating the possibilities of other foreign learning methods.

- Case+ Method: When it is necessary to prove that a proposition holds true under various conditions, prove its truthfulness by discussing each case separately.

2. Indirect Argumentation Methods

- Contra- Method: Indirectly confirming the truth of the original proposition by refuting the contrary proposition that contradicts the original one. For example, supporting the view that learning science and technology and resisting decadent culture by eliminating the possibilities of other foreign learning methods.

When it is necessary to prove whether an integer is even or odd:

Suppose n is an integer.

**Case 1: n is even**

If n is even, it can be expressed as n=2k, where k is an integer. According to the definition of even numbers, n is divisible by 2.

**Case 2: n is odd**

If n is odd, it can be expressed as n=2k+1, where k is an integer. According to the definition of odd numbers, n is not divisible by 2 and has a remainder of 1.

Therefore, every integer n can be classified as one case of being either even or odd, thus proving the proposition that any integer is one of the two.

question:
If Li Gua murdered his boss, then he is an evil person. Li Gua did not murder his boss, so Li Gua is not an evil person. This reasoning is obviously unsound. The act of murder (regardless of whether it is the boss) can indeed make a person an evildoer, but evildoers are not limited to murderers; there are many other forms of wrongdoing. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that "Li Gua is not an evil person" from "Li Gua did not murder someone."

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: âˆ€xâˆƒy R(x, y), therefore, âˆƒyâˆ€x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: âˆ€x (Sx â†’ Px), therefore, âˆ€x (Px â†’ Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Â¬Px), it is erroneous to infer âˆƒx (Px âˆ§ Â¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Px) infer âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Â¬Px), and from âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Â¬Px) infer âˆƒx (Sx âˆ§ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
